What i'm saying is i think i might have chipped a tooth on a few pieces.  But i can never hate on pork too much - i have a deep and profound relationship with pig products and it doesnt feel right to hate.

After my first few bites a large piece of the burrito broke off and fell in my lap and  I had to pick pinto beans out of my crotch.  Trust me, its not as sexy as it sounds.

No salsa bar - seriously, what the hell is going on here?

I felt really helpless and vulnerable, my Saturday afternoon had been completely sabotaged.  My butthole hurt.

Broken and defeated, Annie and I retreated indoors and proceeded to get ridiculously drunk hoping to purge our minds of the atrocities we endured.  It didnt work, but i did throw up later and lost the burrito in the process. 

 Its the small victories in life that i cherish the most.
author: Kirsten S.

description:
Burrito fail. My first visit, got a super carnitas burrito - and requested it without salsa or cilantro as the green herb tastes like soap to me.

Alas, my burrito was packed with cilantro. So much so that I couldn't forgive it as a mild case of "cilantro contamination" of another ingredient like the onions, which is common and understandable.

And, considering it was a a super burrito, the thin slices of avocado were stingy at a count of only two.

The carnitas were well flavored, though more a stewed, shredded pork than a greasy, crispy carnitas. Very little fat blobs, which have ruined other carnitas for me.

I'll give it another chance, but reluctantly.
author: Lauren G.

description:
I'm am so glad to here people like this place.  I used to live basically across the street from here.  My housemate said it wasn't very good so I avoided it for a while.  But one day I couldn't resist any longer, as I do love mexican food.  They will make your burrito how ever you want it.  They don't advertise this but if you're really nice to them they will do it.
Maybe it was because I went there a lot... anyways.

I would always ask for a "quesadilla" with black beans and rice, tomato's and avocado.  Basically it's a burrito grilled with lots of cheese.  Weird I know.  But AMAZING!!!  They never get mad either, even though they are right next to pop's and get all the ruffian from the hood coming in at all hours.  

I LOVE THIS PLACE.
author: amanda v.

description: This place rocks, quick, cheap and great burrito's. i love the salsa and cold beer.
author: Greg W.

description: Fish taco was A+. Super tender pieces of [fish type?] piled on the recular taco fixings. Salsas are hotter than other not as legit taquerias. The burrito will go in my stomach next.
author: Ray C.

description:
Best burrito I've had in SF ever.

I've made comments in other reviews before that my being from Southern Cali has made me snobby when it comes to Mexican food.  Down there, cheap Mexican food is usually better than any fancy restaurant and more plentiful.  

Around here?  Bleh.  It's cheap, but crappy.  Really poor quality.

This place has officially impressed me.  I've never been inside, my coworker called me and asked me if I wanted a burrito for lunch.  I reluctantly said yes.  When he brought me this chicken burrito, with fresh celantro and avocado...omg.  Everything was warm and juicy, it's the best I've had in SF.  (working on 2nd year here)
author: Mary R.

description: Best taqueria in SF!  High quality meats, fresh ingredients - and their burrito is always perfectly proportioned. Al pastor, carne asada, carnitas - all great. El Farolito used to be our favorite until we found this place.
author: Alison J.

description:
Despite the somewhat seedy area and lack of ambiance, this place has remained my favorite no-nonsense burrito joint since 1998.  Bluntly put, the place itself is nothing special.  Simulated wood tables dot the dining area, while a drop ceiling and fluorescent lights illuminate from overhead.  At least one set of lights is always sporadically fluttering, it's bulbs or ballasts going into a slow dance of death.  Excited, animated Spanish voices radiate from the TV when a Mexican soccer game is being televised... Mariachi tunes blare from the jukebox if one isn't.

Located about two blocks from Potrero Ave., this place is far enough from the nauseatingly trendy Valencia St. corridor to be devoid of any influence from the wrong things, but deep enough inside the Mission to be influenced by the right things.

I always get a Chicken burrito here, and the Chicken is ALMOST on par with that of the uber-spendy La Taqueria (see my other review on this) on Mission Street.  Chips are free, and each table has a full jar of salsa on it.  I regularly kill an entire jar... and nobody ever says anything when I snarf a fresh one off an adjoining table.  Seating and lines are NEVER a problem, even at high noon on the weekdays.  Bicycle riders rejoice....I've brought my steed inside many times, and the staff has never so much as batted an eye.

Check it out, but don't bring too many friends...especially if they aren't from the Mission.  This place is one of my last remaining neighborhood secrets....and I'd be devastated if the Valencia street mod-squad sniffed it out and made it hip....

Update: 4-02-06 burritoeater.com got written up in the Chron, ( http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2006/04/02/CMGU9GJ0Q51.DTL&hw=burrito&sn=001&sc=1000 ) And so did this place along with it.   There goes the neighborhood....
author: Mike W.

description:
There burrito people and taco people. I am a taco person. Taqueria San Francisco is by far my most favorite joint for al pastor tacos. Carnitas are ok. Lengua is ok. But the al pastor, seriously heaven in spicy pork form.

+5 for delicious tacos
who cares about ambiance?
author: Glenn E.

description:
Nothing fancy to look at but man that chicken taco was delicious. It was juicy, spicy and perfect!  And it was all white shredded meat.  I was very happy and now I'm craving more tacos from this place. 

Don't be fooled by the lack of chi-chi decor.

YUM.
author: Liz H.

description: Meh. I was really excited to try Taqueria SF but was sadly disappointed.  I ordered a super carne asada burrito without sour cream and took it home to eat. I thought the tortilla was good, nice and soft, but as soon as I bit into it I was so bummed! The flavor was lacking because the carne asada consisted of teeny teeny tinsy little particles of meat that tasted nothing of carne asada. No juiciness, no yummy meaty flavor, just one sad burrito-file   :(
author: Pola C.

description:
I used to live down the street from here and it was a regular Saturday afternoon lunch place for me.  Great salsa and chips, loved the soft tacos and the chicken burritos.  Yeah, bare bones, but who cares?  I don't go to a taco or burrito joint for the atmosphere.  If you want atmosphere, go check out the car wash burrito place off Bayshore x 101.

Nice fruit drinks, horchata is tasty.  And the price is always right.
author: .Hon H.

description:
Hi, this is one of the best burritos you'll get in the city.

Cheap. Deli-cious.

Ya know why? 

They grill the burritos instead of steaming the tortilla.

And they have salsa ON THE TABLE.

And they're across the street from Pop's.

That's why.
author: Danyell K.

description: Great Mexican takeout. They make all their own tortillas right there!! Not expensive either.
author: Andrew X.

description: This place has the best tacos in San Francisco. Haven't had there burritos yet because I can't get enough of there al pastor tacos.
author: Colin H.

description:
There is a man that works here who completely ignores what you order and instead makes the burritos how HE thinks that they should be. He has screwed up my order so many times that I honestly think that he does it purposely
"No CHEESE? I'll show you cheese m.f."
"No SOURCREAM? Your getting sour cream M.F."
author: fuck you p.

description:
Ok, so the chips are pre-made and tastes like Doritos. The "fresh" pineapple juice is from a can. There is no beautiful salsa bar with roasted peppers. And there is no arsenal of smiling ladies in matching aprons and paper hats. 

But the carnitas here is RAD. It is wonderfully tender and flavorful in a way that only pork fat can ensure. The tortillas are warmed and act as the perfect conveyance for the carnitas. Two carnitas tacos and a Mexican Coke make Taqueria SF a wonderful destination in the Mission.
author: Dana H.

description:
Bar none, my favorite place for mexican food in the city. The carne asada super burrito is so flavorful and juicy, without being messy and getting all over the place. I first discovered this when I lived down the block on 24th and now drive out of my way to pick burritos up from here.

The guys behind the counter and nice dudes too. They sell t-shirts too...of which I am a proud owner.

Recommendations:
- Carne Asada super burrito
- Chicken Quesadilla
- T-shirt
author: Rondeep C.

description:
yup burritoeater.com led me here too, and I too was unimpressed....
vs Cancun, Castillito, I thought they were all better.  It's a good and cheap burrito, but I wouldn't call it the best burrito in the city.  Also, the agua fresca (pineapple and peach) were made from canned fruit... not really very fresca now, is it?
my friend got a pastor taco.  I got a carne asada burrito.  Carne asada was kinda bland.  Pastor was nowhere near cancun or castillito level of tastiness.  salsa was good though.  nice balance of spiciness and flavor.
El Farolito is just down the street...  you know what to do.
author: Fong L.

description:
Carne Asada Super Burrito

Full disclosure: I read all about this spot on B.E. and this page. So the hype meter pegged deep into the red as we made our way up to the Mission for a show at the Make-out Club a couple of nights ago. And boy howdy, this notoriously heavy hitter came through in a big way.

The burrito came to the table thinner than the ones I had been dreaming about. Maybe they are trimming down for the upcoming World Cup? I was immediately impressed by how tight they wrapped the foil around the burrito. Like no wrinkles. It was sort of like this beautiful cylindrical mirror, reflecting back an image of me distorted by desire and hunger.

Inside this gigantic silver bullet casing was perfectly proportioned rice and beans, thick chunks of ripe avocado and weapons-grade carne. Oh, the carne asada; seasoned to the hilt, slightly charred edges and juicy insides and a heaping heap of the good stuff.

Yummers.
author: Morga n.

description:
Mojado.  That's the short story of my five-star review.

Taq. SF always delivers the goods, as long as those goods are burrito-esque; Maria D. is right on that the nachos are not the secret to their success.

Hits:

1) Burritos range from large to extra-large.  I have never seen one that was less than above-average in size.

2) Al pastor -- even though I have not been around when the spit is spinning, they have one.   They sometimes chop the meat a little too finely, but that's about the worst I can say about it.  It's got flavor.

3) Pico - they only have one kind in a jar on each table, but it's a one-hit wonder.  I rarely eat more than a few of the factory-made chips at any taqueria, but the pico here is simple, well balanced, and vinegary enough to cut through some grease without being overpowering.

4) The burrito mojado is a sight to behold.  Nice presentation, good ingredient mix, lots of meat, and overflowing with cheese, guac, and sauce (no sour cream for me).  The only thing that would make it better would be extra cheese placed inside the burrito (in addition to the abundant cheese on it) to hold the ingredients together a little more.

No misses.  The employees are courteous, the bathroom is reasonably clean, and the kitchen is in full view to assuage any concerns about cleanliness (the kitchen floor was a little dirty, but gravity works like that, and the counters were all good).
author: Steve K.

description:
Nasty carne asada...the meat is stale as hell and their burritos are filled with too many rice and beans.  No decent salsa selection either.
Also, they'll try to overcharge you.
author: Johan E.

description:
You certainly can't give Taqueria San Francisco stars based on atmosphere but they make the best carne asada burrito I've ever had.  As someone who was a loyal el faralito consumer for 4+ years I don't make that claim lightly.  To those who say el faralito makes a better burrito, I wonder how often they eat there.  As someone who eats burritos weekly I love el faralito still, but consistency isn't their strongpoint.  I've reached the bottom 1/4 on numerous occasions to only find myself staring at a pile of rice and nothing else.  So now when the burrito calls I walk past el faralito (2 blocks from my house) and make the admittedly out of the way trek to Taqueria San Francisco.  I'll still bring out of town friends to el faralito for the experience or myself for late night cravings (TSF isn't late night), but hands down its Taqueria SF if I want carne asada flavor.

And no Rick, they wouldn't call it a burriteria.
author: Mikey P.

description:
I can rarely pass up Manivanh's Thai food which is just 
down the street on 24th but, when I finish a case at San 
Francisco General AFTER Manivanh is closed, I head 
straight for Taqueria San Francisco - I thoroughly relish
the indulgence in a carne asada burrito with its 
succulent meat cooked to perfection - and all the 
trimmings.  So what if it's laden with calories!!!  Maybe I
'll get a second one for lunch tomorrow!
author: Carmen H.

description:
How much better is this place that Farolito?  I can't even begin to tell you. Everything about it is better, the balance of things in the burrito, the atmosphere inside the restaurant, the quality of the beans and rice (bitter beans?  what does that even mean?) Yeah, everything. 

Why do people like Farolito, then, you ask?  I don't really know.  It has to be that they haven't heard that Taqueria San Francisco is right down the street.  Oh, and also, they close at like 9:30 for some ridiculous reason.

I just ate here last night and it was so good that when I finished my burrito I eyeballed my roommate's until she gobbled up the last precious little bite.  And I was pissed.  Seriously, its so good that youll be a ridiculous person.  

I can't believe I kept going to Farolito for so long. 

Oh and their green salsa is just as good, if not better.  Although their chips SUCK.  Seriously, guys, get some new chips.
author: Bill P.

description:
Super Carnitas Taco. Built with love and care. First bite, I felt the love.
Second bite, I knew someone cared about the quality of the food here.
Third bite, the taco was gone and I was longing to order another but
I dragged my ass out. Very good food. The burritos are awesome as well but I stay away from those to try and keep my ass small enough to
drag it away quickly when my self control wanes.
author: Cindy J.

description:
Hmm....It's hard to say how I feel about this place. I was on mission about to check out the "La Palma" Mexicatessen because I heard here on yelp they were pretty badass, but alas, they were closed. So I popped by this place. 

Didn't expect to have spot on service (and you shouldn't either) because this is the equivalent of a sort of gourmet fast food joint. I ordered the standard burrito, and for the 5 something that I paid, it was pretty huge. Then again, I can't say it tasted great nor can I say that it was terrible. It was sort of devoid of flavor, yet still it had some old fashion mexican goodness to it. 

The Chips were a let down because I was really hoping to get some actual hand fried stuff, but the dude scooped it out of a box that looked like the chips were shipped to them from texas (okay not really). They have salsa stuffs at the table and I loved the salsa because it was definitely fresh stuff and tasted great. Oh and ask for water because that stuff is spicy as hell. Mmmm...jalapeos.... 

All in all, It's a pretty average place (especially since its on the mission). I'm sure there are better places on the mission out there somewhere, but this places wasn't bad. Then again, nor was it good.
author: Dzu N.

description:
I have been here a number of times in the past, with great results. Apparently they have shifted staff in recent days. I guess it takes a while to catch up. 

My manpal went out and ordered me a vegetarian quesadilla tonite, but returned with (shudder) a carne asada. I was so pissed that, after he finished eating, I did not even want to go back for the 14 block round trip, but he insisted. 

Thank my stars his conversational skills always dazzle me most while strolling. 

The main man at the shop looked around angrily at the cooks when we explained the predicament. The MP wanted to tell them that I am also muslim, but I had to decline on the grounds that I'm disinclined to misuse other persons religious/dietary restrictions for my own not-so-evil ends. 

In a few minutes, we looked at it to ensure a lack of meat. I got home and discovered that it was a goldarned vegetarian BURRITO. I am sick to death of rice and beans. That's why I didn't order that-either time we went today. Almost no cheese! I'm not saying it was of poor quality, just that we went twice, and I didn't get what I ordered either time. WTF? 

28 total blocks of walking and I still got F***ed. Good thing it was only for a few dollars. Persons with dietary concerns, large or small, wait a while and see if some semblance of order returns!
author: dodie L.

description: better than many overrated taquerias in the mission , when you see people latin people there you can already tell that this place is pretty authentic , pastor super taco was amazing, and the burrito did not fall apart for once they know how to put the right amount of things, overall good experience , oh and that salsa verde they give you with your chips Soooo goood ..
author: NAEL K.

description: beef burrito ot shrmip burrito thats all i want from here,I love this place its one of my fav work lunch spot...SO GOOD!
author: Nina B.

description:
Legit - nuff said.

Had a mojado burrito with al pastor and was not disappointed. The burrito was huge and came doused with cheese, sour cream, onions, and a couple different sauces/salsas. I made a point of finishing all 4 lbs of it and was very content. The chips/salsa verde they provide are a nice little compliment to the meal. They also serve a slew of Mexican beers which I thought was cool (no taquerias in my neighborhood - boston - that serve beers). TVs with futbol playing non stop are another plus. I am not Mexican but the place seemed like a pretty authentic joint to me.

so happy with my meal that I purchased a T-shirt to bring home with me
author: Sean P.

description: This is typically my favorite SF style burrito place.  For SD style burritos, it sucks.  Zero guac, chewy meat (I usually get carnitas here so this was unexpected), way to much pico de gallo.  Again, I am in search of an SD style burrito and not an SF style burrito so I can't award points for what I think is generally a good taqueria.
author: Paul M.

description:
their chips and salsa is the worst i have ever had...

carne asada is ok, and carnitas is so-so

this is a hole in a wall you want to avoid if you are looking for a good food, there's a LOT of better one's down the street.
author: Gors P.

description:
I guess I'd give this 2 and a half stars, if Yelp offered that option. These are decent burritos and decent tacos but nothing to write home about. The salsa is good, but not great, and the atmosphere -- well what do you expect from a taqueria in this seedy neighborhood anyway?

No frills, fills the stomach, gives you gas. To some that's what burritos are for, but I like a little extra something in mine. You won't find it here.
author: Alan R.

description:
I'm on a mission.  In the Mission.   I need to find my "go to" burrito place in my new neighborhood...you'd think that wouldn't be a challenge down here.    Taqueria SF has some good yelp reviews and looks clean inside in comparison to other spots in the 'hood so I thought I'd check it out.  

First of all, my dream of swimming in a sea of cheap mexican food is quickly dying.  It seems that even deep in the Mission I'm paying the same as anywhere else in the City.   I miss my $4 Oakland burritos.   $6 hurts.  

The counter guy was pretty friendly so that's cool.  I got a chicken burrito, which admittedly isn't my favorite in general, but I was in the mood.   It wasn't bad.....but it wasn't "it" either.   The chicken was well seasoned if perhaps a bit too salty...and the salsa was also a bit salty as well as a touch too sour...like many lemons were killed in the process of it's creation or something.   

Perhaps I'll come back for the much hyped carne asada sometime...but for now, the search continues....
author: Scott W.

description:
Best...burrito...ever.

I work just two blocks from this burrito gem.  I have been going there for over a year now and have never been disappointed.  The super carne asade burrito is the highest rated burrito ever over at BurritoEater and it's my meal of choice everytime.

The staff is friendly, the food is fresh, the service is quick and the price is good.

I've tried a whole slew of other burrito shops here in the mission area (Faralito, El Metate, and many more) but none can amount to the deliciousness and reliability of Taqueria SF.

I eat one almost weekly....and it shows.
author: James G.

description:
A nearly perfect burrito - roast pork "Carnitas" on a flaky grilled tortilla - rice and beans done right - spectacular hot, hot salsa - guacamole that didn't just disappear into the mix.

All that, and from some of the friendliest people along 24th Street. I'll be back. And I'm telling my friends too.
author: Brian C.

description:
I've been mulling it over for a while, and I have to say, I was really pretty harsh on good ol' SF Taqueria.  I'm sorry guys.

I gave it another shot... Here is what I have to say:

The chips are actually B grade.  I love the crunch factor, but the salt should get cut down a lot.  I am also pretty into the salsa that they have on every table, but really guys, am I supposed to dip into a communal salsa bowl?  Jeez.

I punished three tacos recently, and I was actually impressed.  They were good.  Chicken, and al pastor.  I'm down with it.  Not as good as Vallarta, but then again, what is.

In closing, Im cool with Taqueria San Francisco.  And I am glad I gave them another chance.

Grade B chips.
author: will h.

description:
I only go here for one thing on the menu - The "Super quesadilla Suiza with carne asada" and that's it. Ordering the super versus the regular means that they add avocado, sour cream and pico de gallo salsa. It is an explosion of flavors and yummy greasiness.  It's cheap, yummy and a must!

It's a basic taqueria dive with not much atmosphere.

$6.25  

*Cash Only*
author: Angelica F.

description: SUPER CARNE ASADA BURRITO (4.5/5) - Ordered according to BurritoEater's high rating: http://www.burritoeater.com/restaurant.php?taqueria_id=126. The lime-tinged pico de gallo brought just the right tang.
author: David G.

description: Nothin but good stuff here! Another regular stop for me while in the mission. Grab a burrito and head over to Potrero del Sol park.....good times and great food.
author: Steven M.

description:
I don't know if this the best burrito, but it is up there.  

I think the grilling of the tortilla, the type of cheese they use, and maybe a bit of different flavors to the meat, make the burritos standout.  

They could use better chips though.
author: Reginald F.

description:
GET THE VEGGIE BURRITO and get over it
the chicken admittedley is kind of lame and the nachos are a no go
but damn that toast that tortilla for the burrito the way you know you want it- not all soggy steamy-
and fresh fresh fresh avocado not some soupy guac inside!
yay yay yay
author: eve e.

description: Quit yer bellyachin already.  Six bucks is the new four bucks.   Your entitled first-world ass is bitching about two dollars?  Get a job.
author: Nick D.

description: Go here for the burritos. This place rocks for the burritos. I don't waste my time with anything else on the menu. The wet burrito (you know that one with all the sauce and other deliciousness on top) is the super awesome. Not super huge but enough to make you feel stuffed and wobbly.
author: Lettie M.

description: I would have to crown this the best burrito establishment I have ever visited. What sets them apart is the way they slice their carne asada.
author: Scott F.

description: Also came here via BurritoEater and love it! Gently grilled tortilla for my Carne Asada regular, and the man at the counter smiled and seemed genuinely very kind. I always come here on trips to the Mission, even if this mixed bag of reviews is making me doubt my burrito taste buds.
author: Steve M.

description: The burritos here are what make living in San Francisco worthwhile. I try not to eat burritos more than once a week, but this place is one of the best. The carne asada isn't as fresh as Papalote or cubed as Cancun on 18th, but it is super flavorful and juicy without being watery. I like how they grill the tortillas before they are served. The super nachos and quesadillas are also pretty awesome. Another plus is the location that is off the crowded part of Mission so it's easy to go there for a quick dinner when parking is tough where the other taquerias are. I just wished they opened later!
author: Mark Y.

description:
Wow. Quite frankly I'm amazed at how divisive Taqueria San Francisco is amongst the yelping community. Initially I didn't even think to review this place because I figured the praise would be nearly uniform, but I suppose there is a debate to weigh in on, so here's my two cents.

It appears that negative reviewers of Taqueria San Francisco can be grouped in to two categories: those who are mistakenly eating non-burrito items off the menu, and those who are totally clueless as to what one should expect from a burrito. Those in the former group can easily rectify the situation, and if they are not a subset of the latter group, problem solved. Those in the latter group who are putting inferior meats like chicken in the burrito or complaining that the salsa is too hot, I can try and present my argument for why the Taqueria San Francisco burrito is the only burrito that I will probably ever give a five star rating on this site.

The essence of TSF's burritos are the construction, which several people before my have eluded to. The tortilla is grilled, which is obviously superior to steaming, but the manner in which TSF grills creates a flakiness that I have never found in other burritos. It's almost as if you're eating a quesadilla tortilla, and really the only reason to eat a quesadilla and not a burrito is for that tortilla texture. The wrapping technique is always tight, and the contents are uniformly distributed within. 

Yes, there is a lot of avocado, and the avocado are wedges, and not guacamole, which I think is a sign of the freshness of the ingredients. I've never thought that to be a negative thing, but it's a fair complaint. The meat selection is typical for a good burrito place; aside from the normal asada-pastor-carnitas trifecta, they serve meats that you don't get at the place that serves the "best nachos in the city" (lengua, cabeza, chorizo). It's tender, juicy and each one has a unique taste. Beans and rice are as good as beans and rice get. They are there to play a minor flavor role, and mostly are a way to get more meat juice into your mouth and not at the bottom of your tortilla. The salsa is contentious, I will admit. It isn't very spicy, but it is unique in that there is an interesting pickled jalapeno flavor in the pico. For those who want more heat, adding the whole jalapenos that are also available on the table should allow one to adjust the spiciness to their desired level, which I think is preferable to making every burrito really spicy.

So that's my take on the restaurant that has given me the most complete and satisfying burrito experience time and again. I hope this helps clarify some of the debate, and if not, I know of a great Mexican place with a seven layer burrito to die for that we can all go to and discuss this further.
author: Brian H.

description: Had the Carne Asada burrito..man o man it was good. Not a lot of ambiance for dining in, but one of the best burritos in town! Thank god is around the corner from my new home! I love when cool things are super close - I foresee a future of burrito parties at my house.
author: Anne Sophie B.

description: If I had to vote today on my favorite Burrito in San Francisco, this would be it. Taqueria San Francisco delivers on every element important to making an amazing burrito amazing. The tightness of the roll, the tinfoil, the fresh ingredients with a good mix so that every bite explodes with flavor, the girth, and the price. Everyone of these categories is achieved to the highest level with each burrito I order here. I switch up my orders from time to time from a carne asada to a grilled chicken burrito and have found both to be damn good with a super carne asada taking the hands down vote of the very reason why I come here in the first place. I usually find parking right in front which is just another bonus to make me smile. Your going to love it!
author: Michael G.

description: Hell Yeah!  This place rocks.  My favorite is the super burito carne asada.  Burrito is the size of a baby's arm.
author: Bill S.

description: I don't like this as much as El Farolito, but the owner takes pride in his store, and it feels more like a family owned place than Farolito.  I love their burritos, and you don't have to pay for chips.  The horchatta is a lot better here than Farolito.
author: Ben H.

description:
I love burritos.  This is the first time that I can remember that I did not finish (or even come close) a burrito.  The flavoring of the chicken was awful.  The cheese (on the super burrito) was overwhelming.  It was an awful burrito.  I have no idea why people rave about this place.

I can say, though, that the salsa was delicious.

Head down the street to Paplote instead!
author: C. J. W.

description: They do a very serviceable al pastor here.  Two super tacos for $6 seems steep, though.
author: Nathan W.

description: Worst nachos I've had in the city.  With over a dozen places in the area that sell every variety of delicious Mexican cheeses Taqueria San Francisco put freaking canned cheese on my nachos...  Like at the ballpark... Cheese Whiz... damn.  Maybe something else there is good, but hell if I'll ever find out.
author: matthew w.

description: Their super-burritos are as good as they get, as well as their tacos and fresh salsas. They recently redecorated their walls with a collection of very large San Francisco photographic panoramas..
author: Victor M.

description: I too went here because of burritoeater.com, and I too was somewhat underwhelmed. Don't get me wrong -- the burrito was just fine, certainly not bad. (Rick H., perhaps you should've have a burrito instead of tacos?) But it didn't knock my socks off, and it wasn't better than my neighborhood place's, La Corneta's, burritos. I wouldn't go out of my way to go here again, but it's fine if you're in the area. Positives: Grilled tortilla, addition of cilantro and onion, manageable size. Minuses: Cardboard-y store-bought chips (not even Casa Sanchez brand), forgot to include my guacamole add-on, bland boiled chicken (I prefer it grilled).
author: Tara M.

description: I am yet another burritoeater.com inspired visitor.  I guess I just don't get it.  I had the carne asada super burrito, and it was just your average Mission burrito.  The horchata was okay, if a bit watery.  El Farolito kills this place.  It wasn't bad, but I doubt I'll come back.
author: Ficus K.

description: Stumbled upon this place by accident on my way to the airport.  Super duper excited about my taco...this one piece of mexican cuisine might have changed my whole taco outlook.  I was never a fan until I  experienced the veg taco, the wierd thing is...huge carnivore....huge burrito fan.  Who was that girl?  Well a girl who loved the ripe avacado on her taco, a girl who couldn't get enough of the fresh red and green salsa.  Can't wait to see what they have up their sleeve as far as burritos.
author: Brye L.

description: carnitas.....good.  pollo & carne asada very mediocre. Chips are kind of lame too.  I thought I wouldn't like their chunky salsa in dirty bowls on the tables, but it wasn't bad and had a great kick. Not the best joint in town, but if you're going get carnitas, they are yummy.
author: Nima K.

description: They make the best effing burrito I've had in my life. I almost wet myself out of joy. If it weren't such a freaking trek for me, I would eat here every day.
author: C P.

description: Hmm.. this place was merely mediocre. My friends and I went here because of its high rating on burritoeater.com. We had the wet burrito (umm, we didn't know it would be wet. Lol. I didn't read the last part on the menu, "cheese, sourcream, sauce,.....ON TOP"), and it was kind of greasy. I also got a horrible stomach afterwards (not sure if it was from eating 1/2 a burrito at Papalote and 1/2 here). GO TO PAPALOTE instead! About 8 blocks up 24th St.
author: O K.

description: I work at The General and have been enjoying the burritos and the quesadilla suizas at this place for years.  What can I say, it's close to work, the crew is cool and I love the bowl of jalapenos on the table, I must down two or three before I finish up.
author: ein bier bitte k.

description: Booo to the SF Weekly Best of San Francisco!  went to this place because it was listed as best burrito.  The beef had an odd taste, the chips are grade C, and the al pastor meat was ultra greasy (inedible).  the only good thing was the salsa in the "little cup" on the table!!!  the whole experience was extremely upsetting and disappointing!!!  and, yes, as another reviewer wrote, the rice had a sort of congee consistency, and a couple hours later i felt slightly ill.
author: suzanne e.

description: Gotta agree with some of the negative yelp reviewers. Came here for some post-happy hour grub (I'm actually kinda drunk writing this) tonight based on a rec from my co-worker and it disappointed. I got the carne asado burrito "mojado" with their fiery hot green salsa, sour cream and red sauce on top. Jesus it was freaking spicy! Too much tortilla, not enough meat and in my book, that's b.s. My guy had the tamales dinner and he remarked the corn and meat were waaaay overcooked. We were full, but not satisfied. Doubt we'll be back--we're fans of La Corneta personally.
author: Genevieve R.

description:
Below is my original review. I have changed my mind. I went there twice this week [the 2nd time was to return my burrito] and they gave me the wrong order both times. The first time I was handed a carne asada burrito, which great except I am not a beef or pork eater. 

Cool, people make mistakes. I take it back up and they give me another carne asada burrito, this time in a spinach tortilla. WTF?

I take it back up, and they are like sorry, come back tomorrow; it's closing time. 

I agree, it is time I close the book on these 2-bit bastards. I will not go to Taq. SF under any conditions whatsoever in the future. They are grade A douchebags for messing up that much, though I deserve part of the blame for eating so late in the day and not checking immediately what I ordered. 

Oh well, it is a learning experience.

===

The grilled chicken burrito is not good. I tried it twice in one week. Very dry, like you are eating sand. 

The tortillas here are among the best in town. The veggie burrito is excellent. 

As another reviewer said, they do a great job with the rice:bean ratio. I firmly recommend Taqueria SF for veggie burritos, but not anything else.
author: Rahul T.

description:
ordered one taco al pastor, one fish taco, and one chile relleno burrito. food was generally ok but nothing spectacular. fish taco did not come with lime - what's up with that?? n sums it up in one word: greaselicious. neither of us really think we need to visit taqueria sf again...especially not with all the other much better choices on 24th.

reading the other reviews, maybe we should have ordered a more traditional (carnitas or al pastor) burrito instead....so maybe i'll give this place another try. but it'll be hard considering all the competition on the same street.
author: Angi C.

description:
San Francisco Taqueira-
Had a regular chicken Burrito........with rice beans and (I think grilled) chicken. Not sure because it was a little dry, yet it was in a red tomato stew. Anyway, tasted like oregano, and although I like oregano, it didn't taste good in a burrito. The best oregano, with garlic, vinegar, and lemon marinated chicken I've ever had was at a Greek golf tournament, and these old Greek guys could Q. Don't get me going, but it was great. I gave the chicken burrito 2 out of 5. I went for the Carne Asada Burrito..... That I've read so much about. It was good, not fantastic, I gave it a 4 out of 5. The best part of the lunch was watching the 3 guys preparing the carne asada. One guy was cutting thin pieces of meat from a whole bottom round, another guy grilled it, while yet another chopped it up on a round cutting board. They all seemed to be having a good time, especially when the female customers left the room. I gave the Carne Asada burrito 4 out of 5. Everything was good about it, but it wasn't a 5.  
It was a pay as you order type deal, cash only. Neat counter to sit at and watch the show with a beer. Very simple menu. These guys made authentic food; they had sesos as a choice of meat. Are sesos considered a meat? I believe these are organs. I'm going back for the beer and converstion.
author: Miguel V.

description: I ate the veggie burrito, which didn't actually contain any veggies.  It didn't matter because everything was very tasty and then they grilled it so it was also melty.  They have salsa on the table, which they had to refill after I left because I emptied the entire container.  Instead of using fresh jalapenos, they used pickled ones, which added another layer of flavor that I wasn't expecting.  I would recommend this Taqueria to anyone.
author: Jody S.

description: Referred here by BurritoEater.com and boy were they on the money. Not the biggest burritos in the world, but so unbelievably flavorful that you always feel like you've had an excellent dinner. Staff are cool too. I always get the carne asada which is pefectly grilled, and best of all they grill (not steam) their tortillas.
author: Neil S.

description: Hands down, my favorite super veggie burrito. Can't beat it. I am a fiend.
author: Bete S.

description: I also tried this place based on burritoeater.com and I was impresed.  I have different taste from the reviewers at that site (they place a strong emphasis on cheese, while I can do without), however, I really like this place.  Good food & prices, friendly people.  Thumbs up.
author: Val U.

description: The chile relleno burrito is delicious. Their tortillas are super soft and warm. Friendly, accommodating staff.
author: Karen C.

description:
My corner-block-burrito-joint.
I am a proud loyal customer.  
A lotta of love for these guys.
Carne of choice: Al Pastor

Buy a shirt!!!
author: Dan J.

description:
indeed this place is a popular spot for SFGH employees to go to...it's about 3 blocks away and takes about 5minutes to walk there.  

their menu is simple, yet it was still so hard for me to make up my mind about what i wanted!  I ended up going with my friend's recommendation about their tacos - fish tacos and a beef taco for $5.48 with a free basket of chips. YuMmM  Food came out quickly and was even brought to our table!  The tacos though small, were covered in tons of meat and fish.  The meat literally took up the entire taco, as did the pieces of fish.  I didn't know how to eat it without meat falling out!  Both tacos were very tasty.  I can't wait to try their burrito =P  Of worthy note... their salsa --chopped up tomatoes, onions and cilantro -- looks harmless and looks just like the mild salsa at most other mexican food joints... but BE AWARE... there's also chopped up jalapenos in it!!  despite the ongoing fire in my mouth, i couldn't stop eating it... it was so good.  My 2 other girl friends and i killed the entire jar of salsa on the table =P  Oh, and they have guacomole salsa too! but you have to ask for it.  I wish I knew that ahead of time!

If you're in the area try it, quick, easy and cheap bites.
author: Diane L.

description:
The place was pretty empty, and it was 7ish--this was the first sign that this taq might not be the place to be when in need for a mex fix. But I then thought that I may have stumbled upon a holy taco paradise. So I thought.

I entered. I looked to the left--standard taqueria billboard-menu . Two classes of tacos--regular and super. I asked what was in the "taco regular" (which was $2.25). "Onion, cilantro, hot sauce." "Salsa Roja?" I ask. "Yes." "Two please."

Firstly, there was a puddle of aqua roja in between the tacos. It should not be this consistency. Now, I would be more forgiving if somehow this liquid was tasty, but it really just wasn't.

Even more of a crime than the salsa roja was the carne asada. Simply bland. The carne asada is the integral part of a taco, and they flavored it with a dash too much of nothing. Even salt and lime couldn't save this taco because salt and lime is used to enhance the flavor of the carne asada, but there was no flavor to enhance.

The only decent thing about the tacos were the corn tortillas. It's not even that they were extraordinarily flavorful; they were just well-warmed and had a good consistency. Though this may seem trivial, barely warm, soggy tortillas kind of blow. It's always nice when the tortillas are done right.

I give this a 2-star solely based on the tacos. It's NO BUENO--I would not come here again for the tacos. Note that the rating I give doesn't in any way reflect the restaurant as a whole nor any other items in the menu--it's simply a reflection of the tacos.

-The Taco Guru
author: Taco G.

description: I actually like the atmosphere.  It's your barest taqueria, pretty miss-able from the outside, kind of Beckettish on the inside: the crowning jewel of the decorating scheme was the humungous pile of chopped onions sitting on the kitchen counter for all to see. The long Formica counter has a very American roadside diner feeling, thanks to the register-side coffee pot that was in all likelihood brewed hours ago and a medium sized TV perched on high. In reality the menu might be just as extensive as all the other taquerias out there, but perusing it takes less effort.  They've got fajitas and pescado, and other things that are laid out on a platter, but I've only had their Carne Asada burrito.  It's the best I've ever had. My bio-dad agrees, despite his loyalties to El Toro and Pancho Villa.
author: Reena R.

description: We must have been feeling adventurous when we strolled into the empty Taqueria San Francisco-- my bf ordered the carne adada super burrito meal/dinner with rice and beans.  It was like a burrito-enchilada hybrid, covered in cheese and salsa.  It was totally delicious and survived life in a Styrofoam box as we drove it home.  My risk-taking, however, didn't quite pay off.  I tried a tamale, because I love tamales and I hadn't had one in a while.  Unfortunately, it was super dry and I don't know how common/normal this is, but it had potato in it.  Which wasn't horrible, it was just weird to me.  My apologies if tamales are supposed to have potatoes in them, I'm just a white girl, what do I know?  Anyway, we were the last customers of the night and maybe that tamale had been sitting around all day but I wouldn't try it again.  Stick with the burritos and head somewhere else if you want good chips-- theirs pretty much suck.
author: Kristin P.

description: this is my fav taqueria in san francisco. don't go here expecting a "fresh and healthy" burrito...while the ingredients are fresh the cooking is homestyle so that means no skimping on the grease. their salsa has a vinegar tinge to it that does the trick for a hangover and is good to pour over thier corn chips. the vegetarian burritos and tacos come with huge clumps of avocado in them and are delicious and they always serve up the right amount of cilantro in their concoctions. their staff are especially talented at wrapping your log right so that none of the goodness falls out and your enjoy every last bite- YUM!
author: Adrienne P.

description: This is my favorite taqueria in San Francisco. A highly contested category to be sure, but ohhh, I have never come closer to true burrito perfection than this place. Juicy, well-grilled super carne asada burrito with chips and salsa cruda (well-loaded jars of which are at every table) . . . it's a long walk from the 24th St. Mission BART, but it's worth every inch. Besides, after one of these guys, I could probably walk all the way to Oakland.
author: Adam E.

description: DELICIOUS AND GREAT CUSTOMER SERVICE. Prices are a little higher than other taquerias but well worth it. Their agua de horchata THE BEST. Love all their food speciall the carne al pastor burrito and super nachios with carne asada and jalapenos.YUM
author: Maria H.

description:
i've lived in the mission for a good 10 years and this is as good as it gets.   it is painful to see people raving about places like Metate, Papalote, or worse, places around 16th and Valencia like La Cumbre, El Toro, etc., 

Maybe not for the light of heart - ie people to order chicken or veggie burritos or want a wheat tortilla. Order the carne asada or el pastor.  

Gotta go deep in the barrio to find this gem.
author: baillie p.

description: I was looking forward to coming here for months. I really wanted to like it, esp. because the guy behind the counter was really nice. I got two fish tacos. I also got food poisoning for the first time in my life. I'm never going here again.
author: ratty r.

description: Unlike the other reviewers, I didn't try this place based on burritoeater.com. I, on the other hand, was in the neighborhood and since it reminded me of a taqueria I went to in Mazatlan, Mexico, I figured I'd give it a shot. Ya see, I'm not a burrito fan at all. Burritos drove me away from Mexican food for years, but then I rediscovered the culinary beauty that is the taco. Yes, its the simplicity that wins my heart and my stomach. So of course I ordered two regular tacos, one carne asada and one pollo, received my complementary chips, and began to wait in the damned cold dining room. The doors and windows were open and it was raining outside. Finally, after about 15 minutes, the longest I've ever waited for mexican food, the tacos came to my table. They were actually damned good. The meat was tender and tasty and the tortillas were soft and resilient. The were a bit skimpy on the portions, but all in all it was decent. I would go there again if I were in the neighborhood, but I wouldn't make a special trip for this place.
author: Brandon B.

description: not very impressed by this.  the salsa is delicious, but everything was just missing something. i dont know but it definitely wasn't missing the eggs that auto and i almost got pelted with. egg snipers were throwing eggs at us as we walked down the street.
author: Victor B.

description: best al pastor super burrito i've ever had.  period.
author: stephen a.

description: What's with the bitter beans here?  I've been here twice, I can't recommend the veggie burrito as I hated the flavor of their beans, but my chicken burrito wasn't much better.  This place has supposedly won awards as the best burrito in SF but the judges must have been from Boston where even a bad SF burritto tastes great.
author: Rusty H.

description: While they're not 100% consistent, these are the best burritos in town.  They lightly toast the tortilla's which is money, and the fixings are legit.  A bit out of the way... but interesting.
author: Ken M.

description: best carne asada burrito in san francisco, fried with lard, and a substantial amount of cilantro.  very much like the burritos were here in san francisco in the 80s. edible as a regular burrito. and they leave the jjalapenos escabeche on the table in a bowl, very original san francisco style, not like taquerias of today.
author: christopher a.

description: My stomach just started spontaneously growling as I thought about writing this review. Seriously. I can't even count the number of alternatives I walked by on my way to Taqueria SF, but I am so glad I kept on walking and made it to my intended destination. I will continue to walk by those other places and go just a wee bit further to get to the best burrito in the city. So good! I am a huge fan of the narrower shape, it makes it much more manageable than some of the super fat burritos out there. Don't get me wrong, I'm not girlie about my food, especially not my burritos, but I feel the narrow shape is superior. For one thing, you don't have to stress out about all your fillings spilling out of the tortilla, which makes for a more enjoyable eating experience. There is still a very substantial amount of food, too. I finished mine, but that was based strictly on what my taste buds were telling me to do, it had nothing to do with how much food was in my stomach.
author: Megan M.

description: Outrageously good food.  No ambiance (unless you're a gangster).
author: Andrew G.

description: They make your burrito on the grill. Not steam it, but they literally put the beans and rice on your burrito while its still on the grill. Then they slice fresh avacado ontop. mmm. Their salsas are all very good especially the verde that they give you with chips.
author: jeremy r.

description: their salsa cannot be fucked with. oh man. i got eggs thrown at me while i was walking in here one time or i'd hook it up with a 5 star rating. who is this unknown egg assassin rifiling eggs from the surrounding buildings? i almost got tagged. i saw a car get tagged pretty hard by one. burritos taste good as fuk at this spot
author: Wats C.
